title: Stanton Solitude of Self - Earlier Cause

content.description:
“The strongest reason for giving woman all the opportunities for higher education, for the full development of her faculties, forces of mind and body; for giving her the most enlarged freedom of thought and action; a complete emancipation from all forms of bondage, of custom, dependence, superstition; . . . is the solitude and personal responsibility of her own individual life. The strongest reason why we ask for woman a voice in the government under which she lives; in the religion she is asked to believe; equality in social life, where she is a chief factor; a place in the trades and professions, where she may earn her bread, is because of her birthright to self-sovereignty; because, as an individual, she must rely on herself. No matter how much women prefer to lean, to be protected and supported, nor how much men desire to have them do so, they must make the voyage of life alone.”
Elizabeth Cady Stanton, “The Solitude of Self,” speech to the Judiciary Committee of the House of Representatives, 1892
content.question: Which of the following explains a development after 1865 that most immediately contributed to the historical situation of Stanton’s speech?

choices.label: The spread of evangelical religious revivals encouraged advocacy for equality between men and women.
The gathering of the Seneca Falls Convention led to increased awareness of women’s rights.
The popularization of republican motherhood inspired women’s aspirations for greater political participation.
The expansion of educational opportunities fostered frustration about continuing social limitations for women.

content.answer: The expansion of educational opportunities fostered frustration about continuing social limitations for women.
